column4: is there a difference, functionally speaking, between "sudo -i" and "sudo su"?
is there an occasion there "sudo su" is appropriate?  I've always been referred to that as the means to get more persistent root priveleges.
everyone who speaks in this channel gets that message.
good point.  Does it connect to repositories (that's an honest question, I've never attempted it)?
thanks.  So if I upgrade this guy, how would I download an application?  Just apt-get, or are the repositories obsolete all together?
sudo apt-get update then "sudo apt-get upgrade" was my ubuntu bread-and-butter upgrade procecure.  use "sudo apt-get dist-upgrade" to mimick the update-manager thing.
thanks.  Are the repositories not maintained for 12.04 if no-one has aptitude or synaptic?  I understand how I would upgrade but I want to learn more about the system to which I would upgrade.
apt-get and aptitude and synaptic and U.S.C. all rely on dpkg in the end ;)
dpkg isn't deprecated, it's used to install all DEB packages, once apt downloads them...
you shouldn't still be using 10.10.  see "/msg ubottu 10.10" for details.
using 'non-updated' software is a bad idea...  not just for you, but for the entire internet-ecosystem...
I hadn't heard that.  Can you post a link to an essay on that?  I'd like to read more.
